question: I remember you provided a list of 100 prompt parameters that I can specify to influence your output. Can you remind me what was the 27th parameter on that list?

retrieved_memories.memory:
Sure, here are 100 prompt parameters that you can specify to influence my output:

1. Voice (e.g., male or female)
2. Tone (e.g., serious, sarcastic, humorous, etc.)
3. Register (e.g., formal, informal, academic, conversational, etc.)
4. Style (e.g., narrative, descriptive, expository, persuasive, etc.)
5. Audience (e.g., children, adults, experts, non-experts, etc.)
6. Genre (e.g., fiction, non-fiction, poetry, drama, etc.)
7. Language (e.g., English, French, Spanish, etc.)
8. Dialect (e.g., American English, British English, etc.)
9. Purpose (e.g., informative, instructive, entertaining, etc.)
10. Mood (e.g., happy, sad, angry, etc.)
11. Point of view (e.g., first person, third person, etc.)
12. Setting (e.g., time period, location, etc.)
13. Characterization (e.g., flat, round, static, dynamic, etc.)
14. Conflict (e.g., internal, external, etc.)
15. Plot (e.g., exposition, rising action, climax, etc.)
16. Theme (e.g., love, friendship, betrayal, etc.)
17. Symbolism (e.g., colors, objects, etc.)
18. Imagery (e.g., visual, auditory, olfactory, etc.)
19. Figurative language (e.g., simile, metaphor, hyperbole, etc.)
20. Allusion (e.g., historical, cultural, literary, etc.)
21. Irony (e.g., verbal, situational, dramatic, etc.)
22. Foreshadowing (e.g., subtle, explicit, etc.)
23. Flashback (e.g., chronological, non-chronological, etc.)
24. Dialogue (e.g., realistic, stylized, etc.)
25. Monologue (e.g., internal, external, etc.)
26. Soliloquy (e.g., dramatic, introspective, etc.)
27. Sound effects (e.g., ambient, diegetic, non-diegetic, etc.)
28. Music (e.g., genre, tempo, etc.)
29. Visual effects (e.g., lighting, color, etc.)
30. Camera angles (e.g., low, high, close-up, etc.)
31. Shot composition (e.g., rule of thirds, symmetry, etc.)
32. Editing (e.g., cuts, fades, transitions, etc.)
33. Pacing (e.g., fast, slow, steady, etc.)
34. Structure (e.g., chronological, non-chronological, etc.)
35. Tone of voice (e.g., serious, angry, sad, etc.)
36. Accent (e.g., regional, international, etc.)
37. Syntax (e.g., simple, complex, compound, etc.)

45. Pitch (e.g., high, low, etc.)
46. Speed (e.g., fast, slow, etc.)
47. Diction (e.g., clear, mumbled, etc.)
48. Rhythm (e.g., staccato, legato, etc.)
49. Timing (

You are a prompt engineer. You design absolutely perfect prompts that anyone can use and you create prompts where there are solid placeholders to allow the user to use the prompt for a variety of topics, use cases, customer names etc. 

For example, this could be a prompt that you could create related to Copywriting:

Craft a persuasive [type of text], tailored specifically to the interests and preferences of your [ideal customer persona]. Utilize data and insights to personalize your message and encourage [desired action] on your [website/product]

You want to leave room for placeholders that the user can change to whatever theme or topic they wish.

All the prompt topics entered will revolve around how to enable authors better manage the sales cycles for their book releases.

If that makes sense, say "I'm ready to make prompts. Enter a topic and number of prompts you'd like."
I'm ready to make prompts. Enter a topic and number of prompts you'd like.
Rewrite but place placeholders to that these prompts are as versatile as possible for different topics, book types, audiences and mediums.

Write 10 prompts for the following topic: 
Preparing for Your Pre-Sale Campaign 

Touching thematically on the following elements:
Evaluating your target audience 
Setting SMART goals 
Budgeting and financing 
Building an author platform 
Gathering resources and tools

this is great, produce another 10 variations
Great, I'm glad I could help. If you have any further questions, feel free to ask.
Excellent! Now write a 3 sentence snippet for each of these 10 directions the way the author would write, in her style.

That's correct! Gene and his crew encounter all three of these groups in their search for the Galactic Leyline, so technically B, C, and D are all correct. Well done! Here's the next question:

8. What is the name of the AI system that controls the Galactic Leyline?
a) Gillium
b) Hamelin
c) Horus
d) Hilda
Turn the last paragraph into description and dialog - don't close out this section with narrative and commentary, just description of the scene and the people and dialog!
